div.p: ANTONIO: The four phases of alcohol and drug use aren't tidy boxes we all fit into perfectly.
ANTONIO: We may not experience all the characteristics of a phase, but everyone can recognize their place somewhere along the phase progression.
ANTONIO: As we have seen, the Green Phase is characterized by low-risk choices. When it comes to alcohol, I can ‘take it or leave it.' When it comes to drugs, I leave it.
ANTONIO: The Yellow Phase is marked by high-risk choices. My ‘take it or leave it' attitude changes to anticipation, and I associate drinking and/or drug use with having fun.
ANTONIO: And remember, any drug use automatically puts me in at least the Yellow Phase.

ANTONIO: The Orange Phase is distinguished by psychological dependence where I develop a relationship with drugs or alcohol, and I may develop defenses to protect that relationship.
ANTONIO: In the Orange Phase my drinking or drug use becomes integrated into my daily life, which may lead to extensive state-dependent learning.
ANTONIO: Finally, the Red Phase is characterized by addiction. Here, I have passed my trigger level, and I can't consistently control my drinking or drug use.
ANTONIO: In addition, the spiral can keep me from seeing the ways my alcohol or drug use is causing problems.
ANTONIO: Once I've entered the Red Phase, my only recommended low-risk choice is abstinence.
ANTONIO: And as I progress through the phases, brain changes can make it even harder for me to recognize how my choices are creating problems.
ANTONIO: But it's important to remember that no matter what phase we are in, we can learn to recognize where we are, and choose to make changes. So, we have a choice to make... like in this story.
